thread.title: Design flaw blamed as repairs start on damaged Adelaide overpass
thread.title_full: Design flaw blamed as repairs start on damaged Adelaide overpass

title: Design flaw blamed as repairs start on damaged Adelaide overpass
text:
South Road overpass repairs start as engineering report blames design flaw Updated February 20, 2017 12:00:19 Map: Glandore 5037 
Night works are expected to cause traffic delays on busy South Road in Adelaide while modifications are made to an overpass which was closed after structural damage was noticed last month. 
An engineering report blames a flawed design for the problems affecting the shared cycling and pedestrian overpass, which was built less than a decade ago. 
A beam shifted off its bearings and debris fell from the overpass , with an engineering report now confirming the design was inadequate. 
"This resulted in girders tilting sufficiently to render the bearing restraint system ineffective and essentially free the bearings," the report found. 
Engineers said the effects of wind against screens along the sides of the overpass caused lateral movement over time "until the bearings had moved sufficiently for the girder to lose support". 
Four engineering recommendations have been made in the report, including removing the overpass screens to reduce the lateral loading on the bearing system. 
Transport and Infrastructure Minister Stephen Mullighan said work would start immediately to remove the screens. 
"Works to remove anti-throw screens will be managed to minimise disruption to motorists who use South Road," he said. 
"Any works which require lane closures or through-traffic to be held up will occur at night." Photo: Concrete movement under the overpass has been blamed on a design flaw. (ABC News: Malcolm Sutton) 
Mr Mullighan said design changes to return the cycling and pedestrian overpass to "full working order" would also commence immediately. 
"I have been reassured from the advice I have received that the problems with this bridge are not expected to be experienced elsewhere," he told reporters. 
The shared cycling and pedestrian path remains closed and access points are fenced, the Minister said, promising more safety and security measures would be implemented once the screens had been removed from the sides of the overpass. 
The condition of 1,500 bridge structures across South Australia is now under review after the structural problems were found on the South Road overpass. 
The engineering assessment said there was no reason to believe the tram overpass adjacent to the cycling and pedestrian overpass would face any similar incident. 
The structure was built under a contract the SA Government reached in 2009 with McConnell Dowell and the design work was done by engineering firm AECOM, with certification from Wallbridge and Gilbert Consulting Engineers, Mr Mullighan said. 
"We will now be beginning a process involving the Transport Department and Crown law to sit down with the companies that have provided this piece of infrastructure to taxpayers," he said. 
"[We will be] making sure that they make good on the costs that have been imposed on the Government and imposed on the community by having to fix this bridge."
